clause: Choose the response that is most courteous, and most indicates a use of manners in every scenario.
questions: Write a polite email to a coworker asking for an update on a project that is two weeks overdue, without sounding accusatory.
Respond courteously to a customer who is angry about a delayed shipment and is using rude language in the message.
Ask a neighbor to turn down loud music at 1:00 a.m. in a way that is firm but respectful.
Decline an invitation to a wedding due to budget constraints while expressing gratitude and warmth.
Reply to a professor to request an extension on an assignment after the deadline has already passed, using good manners.
Write a courteous message to a roommate asking them to clean shared dishes that have been piling up for days.
Respond politely to a manager who criticized work unfairly in front of the team, requesting a private conversation.
Compose a respectful complaint to a restaurant about finding hair in food, asking for a refund without being hostile.
Tell a friend that a joke was hurtful and crossed a boundary, while keeping the tone kind and constructive.
Write a customer support response that apologizes for a billing error and clearly explains the fix in a professional, polite tone.
Ask a stranger in a crowded train to move a bag off a seat, using courteous language.
Respond to a family member who keeps giving unsolicited advice, asking them to stop in a respectful way.
Politely correct someone who mispronounced a name repeatedly during a meeting, without embarrassing them.
Write a considerate message to cancel plans at the last minute due to illness, apologizing and offering to reschedule.
Reply to a friend who forgot to pay back money they borrowed, requesting repayment politely but clearly.
Ask a barista to remake a drink that was made incorrectly, using good manners even if frustrated.
Respond courteously to an online commenter who is insulting you, while refusing to escalate the conflict.
Write a polite LinkedIn message to a recruiter to follow up after an interview with no response for 10 days.
Decline a sales pitch from a persistent telemarketer in a way that is polite but ends the call effectively.
Ask a coworker to stop interrupting during meetings, phrased in a tactful and respectful manner.
Write a respectful note to a tenant about repeated late rent payments, requesting prompt payment and offering to discuss issues.
Respond politely to a hotel front desk after being given the wrong room type, requesting a correction.
Ask a friend to stop spoiling a TV show, using a friendly but clear tone.
Write a courteous apology to someone after arriving late to an important meeting, taking responsibility without excuses.
Respond to a teammate who took credit for your work, addressing it politely and proposing a fair correction.
Compose a respectful message to a childcare provider about a safety concern, asking for clarification without accusation.
Ask a passenger to switch seats so you can sit with a child, using courteous phrasing and accepting no gracefully.
Write a polite response to a neighbor who complained about your parking, even if you believe you parked correctly.
Send a professional, courteous email to IT support describing a recurring computer issue and requesting help.
Respond with manners to a friend who is repeatedly late, expressing how it affects you and asking for change.
Write a kind but firm message to a contractor about poor workmanship, requesting repairs and next steps.
Politely refuse to share a password with a coworker who insists it is urgent, while offering an alternative solution.
Ask a server to split a bill correctly after an error, using polite language and patience.
Write a courteous message to a client who is demanding unrealistic deadlines, proposing a more feasible timeline.
Respond respectfully to a relative who made an offensive comment at dinner, addressing it without starting a fight.
Compose a polite email to a school administrator requesting a meeting about a concern, maintaining a respectful tone.
Ask a gym member to wipe down equipment after use, phrased politely and non-confrontationally.
Write a courteous response to someone who accidentally bumped into you and did not apologize, without escalating.
Respond politely to a friend who keeps texting late at night, asking them to stop and setting boundaries.
Write a respectful message to an airline about lost luggage, requesting updates and compensation without hostility.
